5.  An  equally  important  emphasis  in  Phase  IV-Year  1  TA  was  the  effort  to  build
partnerships with  project stakeholders,  including nongovernment organizations  (NGOs), and
local communities to promote better understanding and fuller appreciation of the benefits of
subregional cooperation. A more conscious effort was made to interact with NGOs on project-
related issues as well as on broad issues pertaining to development approaches in the Mekong
subregion. The effort to build  partnerships was also directed to the private business sector
whose  role  in  project  finance  has  become  increasingly  crucial  in  view  of  the  scheduled
completion of project preparation work for a number of investment projects during the period
2000-2002. The GMS Business Forum, launched in October 2000, was a concrete result of this
effort and signaled the  beginning of a more systematic involvement of the private business
sector in the GMS process.  The objectives and progress to date of activities under Phase IV-
Year 1 TA are in Appendix 1.
6.  In  the  course of  implementing  Phase  IV-Year  1  TA,  key  factors  that  require
enhancements in the GMS Program have emerged. The first factor relates to ADB's overarching
goal and commitment to fight poverty in its developing member countries, which has highlighted
a new perspective in subregional cooperation that focuses on poverty reduction. At the Ninth
GMS Ministerial Conference held in January 2000, the GMS countries agreed that the benefits
of  regional  economic  cooperation  must  be  broadened  to  more  directly  benefit  the  poor;
therefore, GMS projects and initiatives should be designed to substantially contribute to poverty
reduction.
7.  The second factor relates to the results of the Impact Evaluation Study of the GMS
Program,  which,  among  others,  called  for  (i)  concrete  steps  to  help  the  GMS  countries
operationalize their sense of ownership of the  Program and to assist them  in building the
capacity for  managing it, and  (ii) strengthening the  links between national and  subregional
programming.  The Impact Evaluation Study also raised a number of important observations on
ADS's  internal constraints  in dealing with the  GMS  Program, including among  others, the
limitations in loan and TA   financing for subregional projects in the eight sectors, lack of staff
resources and inadequate  realignment of staff responsibilities that are  suitable for  regional
programs and projects, poor internal coordination, and weak programming and budgeting for
regional projects.  Many of these issues are being addressed in the Institutional Review of the
GMS  Program conducted  under  Phase  IV-Year 1 TA.  Planned improvements  in the  GMS
institutional mechanisms would be complemented by capacity-building measures in the GMS
countries, which  will  be  addressed  as  part of  the  institutional review.  At  the  same  time,
adjustments in ADS operations pertaining to the GMS Program have been initiated in the areas
of resource allocation, programming, and budgeting.
8.  The third factor pertains to the encouraging results of efforts made under Phase IV-Year
1 TA   to build partnerships with  project stakeholders and the private business sector, which
needs to be reinforced and brought to a higher plane. From past lessons, further improvements
in the mechanisms for involving NGOs and stakeholders in monitoring project-related social and .
environmental impacts will be required. This is particularly relevant in monitoring project-related
impact and disseminating project-related information. As regards private sector participation,
there is now an opportunity to pursue a more targeted approach for mobilizing private sector
financing of specific projects. Project- or sector-specific business promotion seminars within the
framework  of the  GMS  Business  Forum will  be needed to  promote awareness of specific
investment and financing opportunities in the GMS.
9.  At the Ninth GMS Ministerial Meeting held in Manila in January 2000, the six GMS
countries  requested ADB  to  continue  as facilitator and coordinator of  the GMS  Program.
Continuing ADB support would be needed to help the GMS Program address ongoing as well

advisory assistance,a   program of training including a secondments cheme to ADB resident
missionsa nd headquarters,a nd provisiono  f equipmentt o GMS national coordinators'o ffices,
including Intemet access to improve coordinationa nd information-sharingm  echanismsw  ithin

3. Enhance the Participation of Stakeholders at Program and Project Levels,
Including  Monitoring Project Impacts
14.  Considering lessons learned from project implementation issues that were experienced
especially with GMS hydropower projects, Phase IV-Year 2 TA will take concrete steps to work
more closely with project stakeholders and NGOs to ensure adequate and timely monitoring of
the social and environmental impacts of projects. ADB will explore more innovative ways of
working with  NGOs and other stakeholders on early problem detection and quick response
mechanisms. Working  arrangements  with  specific  NGOs with  expertise  or  involvement  in
particular activities will also be initiated through Memorandum of Understanding or executing
agency  arrangements.  In  addition  to  project-level  working  arrangements,  however,
establishment of a regular mechanism for dialogue with NGOs at the policy level will also be
explored to get alternative views on development approaches and program and project design
issues. In this regard, a concept paper will be prepared and NGOs consulted on a proposed
social and environmental advisory group as a regular forum within the GMS Program.
4.  Mobilize  Financial  Resources  for  GMS,  Focusing  on  Private  Sector
Participation  in Specific  Subregional  Projects
15.  Although resource mobilizationi s a continuingo bjective under the GMS Program,t he
GMS Program has reached the stage where it is now possible to market specific investment
opportunitiesf or possible private sector participation. The launching of the GMS Business
Forumi n October 2000 providedt he frameworkf or promotingp ublic-privates ector partnerships
in the GMS. Project- or sector-specifici nvestments eminarsw  ill be conducted as the results of
project preparation work or prei nvestment studies are completed.  The specific investment
areas for which business seminars are planned for 2001 are (i) the East-West Economic
Corridor,a nd (ii) the telecommunications"b ackbone"p roject. The strategy is to promote initial
awareness of these investment opportunities among the business community, to  identify
interested and prospective investors, and to assess alternative financing arrangementsa nd
other requireds teps to reach financialc losure.
5.  Intensify Information Dissemination on the GMS Program to a Wider Public
and  Stakeholders
16.  To keep the  public  informed  on developments  in the GMS,  continuing  work  will  update
the GMS web  site and  make  it user-friendly.  In addition  to information  on the  progress  of GMS
activities  and  projects,  the  GMS  web  site  will  be  expanded  to  contain  information  on  study
findings  and  issues  and  materials  developed  as  part  of  GMS  projects.  A  number  of  GMS
project-specific  web  sites  contain  detailed  information  on project  findings  and  results;  this  will
continue  to be encouraged  and efforts  to link project web  sites to the GMS  home  page will  be
made regularly.  Study findings  will also be developed  into GMS publications  and other media for
wider dissemination  of information  on the GMS.

Appendix 1, page 4
Objective/Activities  Status as of August 2000
. 
Initiated the preparation of a long-teml
strategic framework for the GMS to serve as
the basis for the GMS Program Strategy Paper
to be prepared in 200 1
Consultations with stakeholders,  .  Assisted in and coordinated ADB's
nongovernment organizations (NGOs),  consultations with stakeholders, NGOs and
and members of civil society to promote a  other members of civil society on ADB-assisted
better understanding and fuller  projects
appreciation of subregional cooperation
.  Helped initiate and facilitate mitigation actions,
and prepared responses to NGOs with respect
to issues raised by the latter on the adverse"
social and environmental impacts of GMS
hydropower and other projects
. 
Prepared the publication "A Wealth of
Opportunity: Development Challenges in "the
.  Mekong Region," explaining to a wider set of
publics ADB's thrusts and programs for GMS.
.  Assisted in efforts to encourage the
Government of Lao PDR, its power entity,
Electricite du Laos (EdL), and the private
Theun Hinboun Power Co. (THPC) to take
decisive corrective and compensatory actions
for affected villagers. These actions are to
offset fisheries, gardens, housing, and other
.  losses borne by villagers as a result of the
damming of the river.
. 
Persuaded the Government of Lao PDR to
order a halt in illegall ogginga nd wildlife trade,
~ 
which had increased due to roads built for
hydropower projects
. 
Participated in the Sydney Forum "Accounting
for DevelopmentA: ustraliaa nd ADB in the
I 
Mekong" to promote better interactions with
NGOs. Communications between ADB and the
NGOs on the impact of ADB's hydropower
projects in GMS intensified shortly before and
after the Sydney Forum

16
Appendix 4, page 2
(iv)  prepare resource papers for GMS ministerial conferences, meetings of GMS forums
and/or working groups, and other GMS-related events; and
(v)  participate in consultation and monitoring missions to the GMS countries.
2.  Macroeconomist  (international, 12 person-months)
4. The responsibilities  will be as follows:
(i)  assist in preparing  the GMS Program Strategy Paper (2002-2004);
(ii)  prepare  and  regularly  update  the  analysis  of  macroeconomic  and  demographic
trends,  intraregional  trade and investment flows, and poverty indicators  for the long-
term strategy of the GMS Program;
(iii)  assist  in the  preparatory  work  for  developing  of other  economic  corridors  in the
GMS using the preinvestment  study for the East-West  Economic  Corridor  as a pilot
case;
(iv)  prepare resource papers for GMS ministerial conferences, meetings of GMS forums
and/or working groups, and other GMS-related events; and
(v)  participate in consultation and monitoring missions to the GMS countries.
3.  Development Economist  (domestic, 12 person-months)
5. The responsibilities will be as follows:
(i)  collaborate with the project evaluation specialist in formulating guidelines for the
design and appraisal of regional projects, including the distributional  benefits;
review the application of these guidelines to subregional projects;
(ii)  review and utilize poverty indicators in developing the parameters for the design
and appraisal of subregional projects in terms of their distributional aspects;
(iil)  assist in enhancing the involvement of stakeholders and other members of civil
society in the GMS Program;
(iv)  prepare resource papers for GMS ministerial conferences, meetings of GMS forums
and/or working groups, and other GMS-related events; and
.
(v)  participate in consultation and monitoring missions to the GMS c.ountries.
4.  Senior Project Assistant  (domestic, 12 person months)
6. The responsibilities will be as follows:
(i)  input regular updates to the GMS web page;

11
Appendix  4, page 3
(ii)  assist  in organizing GMS  meetings, including preparing draft  correspondence,
budget estimates, conference venue, and providing overall logistical support;
(iii)  assist in administering the TA   budget and contracting of consulting  se!'Vices;
(iv)  ensure the smooth flow of documents and communications within the GMS Unit,
and between the GMS Unit and Programs Division 3; and
(v)  participate in ADB missions.
5.  Project Assistant  (domestic, 12 person months)
7. The responsibilities will be as follows:
(i)  coordinate with concemed ADB personnel regarding equipment, printing, and other
physical requirements of the GMS Unit;
(ii)  provide layouting services for GMS publications and encoding updates of GMS
maps;
(iii)  assist in providing logistical support in GMS meetings;
(iv)  help disseminate GMS publications; maintain and regularly update the GMS mailing
list; and
(v)  participatein  ADB missions.
c.
Short-Term Experts
Project  Evaluation Specialist/Regional Economist  (international 3  person-
months)
8. The responsibilities  will include the following::
develop,  in  consultation  with  the  Project Evaluation  Division  of  Economics  and
Development  Resource  Center (EDRC),  a set of guidelines  for formulation,  design,
and  appraisal  of  regional  projects,  including  the  distribution  of  benefits  of
subregional  infrastructure  projects;
develop the framework for relating distribution and other benefits of subregional
projects to the poverty status of particular target groups in GMS; and
(iii)  demonstrate the applicability of the guidelines and framework in (i) and (ii) in
selected priority subregional projects.

18 .
Appendix 4, page 4
2.  Development Communications  Specialist (domestic, 4 person-months)
9. The responsibilities will include the following:
(i)  prepare promotional materials on investment opportunities for  selected GMS
projects;
(ii) develop  public  information  materials  based  on  the  technical  reports  of
consultants on (a) the  East-West economic corridor; (b) ethnic  minorities,  (c)
environment projects; and
(iii)  assist in improving the style of the GMS web page to make it more friendly.
.
